snippet: With a clause in complex contracts that few people read, corporations have insulated themselves from lawsuits and locked Americans into a system where arbitrators overwhelmingly favor business.
abstract: Corporations are increasingly inserting individual arbitration clauses into consumer and employment contracts as means of barring people from joining in class action lawsuits; requirement bars citizens from one of few available tools for challenging deceitful or predatory practices, virtually ensuring companies go unpunished; shift has been underway for years (Series: Beware the Fine Print).

byline.original: By JESSICA SILVER-GREENBERG and ROBERT GEBELOFF
